Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Collaborative Research: Fundamental Studies of water-hydrocarbon condensation

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Currently, natural gas supplies ~23% of U.S. energy needs. In addition to CH4, raw natural gas contains water, higher hydrocarbons, and other substances that must be removed before the gas is transported and used. For off-shore wells, treatment near the wellhead is critical to prevent clathrates from forming and plugging the pipeline as gas flows to the mainland. The raw gas is normally treated by adding chemicals or reducing its dew point, but standard processing equipment is often large and requires manned platform operation.

An alternative approach is to use supersonic natural gas separators that (1) cool the gas in a supersonic expansion to induce droplet formation and growth, (2) separate the droplets from the gas, and, (3) recompress the dried gas using a diffuser to minimize pressure losses. These separators are smaller than traditional process equipment, have no moving parts, and require no chemicals. Thus, they are suited for both off-shore and sub-sea applications. Worldwide, three of these devices are now in commercial operation. Twister BV, the industrial partner for this proposal, is at the forefront of developing and implementing this technology. As these devices are adopted, however, critical questions remain regarding droplet formation and growth in these complex vapor mixtures, and these questions are related to the structure of the droplets.

Intellectual Merit:

With an overarching goal of improving the efficiency of natural gas production, this proposal examines droplet formation, growth, and structure in highly non-ideal water hydrocarbon systems under conditions that mimic those found in the supersonic separators. The experimental program will characterize the condensation process in supersonic nozzles, at Mach numbers comparable to the real separators, using pressure measurements and spectroscopy. The resultant aerosols will be characterized using small angle x-ray and/or neutron scattering. The theoretical program will focus on understanding droplet structure, formation and growth rates as a function of the key parameters, i.e., the vapor phase compositions and temperature. Combining the experimental results with the theoretical calculations and detailed modeling will result in more robust descriptions of multicomponent droplet formation and growth that can then be incorporated into the computational fluid dynamics codes used to describe and optimize the performance of supersonic separators. This novel application of computer simulation techniques and density functional theory and of small angle neutron and x-ray scattering experiments is helping transform the field of aerosol science by enabling the solution of problems that previously defied investigation.

Broader Impacts: In a broader context, this work is directed toward improving the energy efficiency of natural gas production. In addition to their relevance to the domestic natural gas industry, as well as to Twister BV, the results stemming from this work are of interest to other researchers in nucleation, aerosol science, and cloud and atmospheric physics. In the area of education and training, this project will provide a rich, highly interdisciplinary research environment for all students and will incorporate a unique international experience for graduate students. Participation in the research by undergraduate students, particularly from minority and underrepresented groups, will be fostered. As an important outreach activity, table top diffusion cloud chambers will be built so that students and teachers can visualize cloud formation in the classroom, a process that is of great interest in elementary and high school education but is not easily realized.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Natural gas is an increasingly important energy source in the United States. What comes out of the ground is not, however, pure methane. Instead raw natural gas typically contains other gases, water, and less volatile hydrocarbon oils. These substances must be removed from the methane before it is sold to consumers. Usually this involves chemical treatment or reducing the temperature enough to condense the water and undesired oils. In either case, the standard approaches require large pieces of equipment and incur significant energy costs.

Recently, natural gas separators have been developed that use a rapid, controlled expansion to cool the gas, force condensation and capture the liquid. Careful design reduces the energy requirements and no chemicals are required. The industrial partner for this proposal, Twister BV (http://www.twisterbv.com/), is the world leader in developing and implementing this technology.

Intellectual Merit

Despite the success of this approach, critical questions remain regarding droplet formation and growth rates in the complex vapor mixtures as they flow through the separator. These questions are not independent of the structure of the droplets. Since water and oil do not mix, one can imagine that even small droplets will have non-uniform structures and that these structures will influence how well water and oil are removed. Our collaborative research effort addressed these questions by employing a sophisticated set of experimental and data analysis techniques, and conducting intensive molecular dynamics simulations.

The experiments investigated water and nonane condensing in a carrier gas of N2 as a model system. We confirmed that when water and nonane co-condense, particle formation rates are not enhanced relative to condensation of the pure species. Rather, in experiments with a fixed concentration of water the number of particles produced decreased as the concentration of nonane increased. This result suggests that nonane actually interferes with water droplet formation – most likely by destroying the smallest water clusters.

In droplet growth experiments conducted with pure water and nonane we found that standard growth theory did an excellent job of predicting the growth rates of pure nonane droplets. Here the growth rate is only limited by how fast vapor molecules reach the droplet surface and the expression based on kinetic gas theory agrees quantitatively with the experimental results. In contrast, for water the arrival rate and the evaporation rate of molecules are comparable and standard theory underestimates both the droplet temperature and the growth rate. Agree is only achieved if we assume there is a barrier to evaporation or an enhancement to vapor capture. We confirmed that these results were not just an artifact of water being in a highly sub-cooled liquid state, by conducting experiments with n-propanol. Once again, theory underestimated the droplet temperature and growth rates. We could explain all of our results by considering the long-range interactions between the vapor molecules and the growing droplets - an idea proposed by Vasil'ev and Reiss [J. Chem Phys. 105, 2946-2947, (1996)]. Not only does this theory predict enhanced growth of water and propanol under our experimental conditions, it also suggests that the nonane droplets are too large for enhanced growth to occur.

Finally, analysis of our small angle X-ray scattering (SAXS) and Fourier transform Infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy experiments demonstrated that multicomponent droplets containing nonane and water do not form spherically symmetric objects.
